Award.AbstractNarration:
The Measurement Approach to Rational Number (MARN) project is a collaborative effort by faculty at New York University, Iowa State University, and the Illinois Institute of Technology that is designing, developing, and testing an innovative approach to elementary students' learning in the critical areas of multiplicative reasoning, fractions, and proportional reasoning. The project team is building on the successful El'Konin-Davydov (E-D) elementary mathematics curriculum that originated in Russia to develop a curriculum framework that can be implemented in U. S. schools.

The MARN project addresses five core research questions about how rational number learning can be developed from a measurement perspective and how sociocultural theory and constructivism can contribute to design of effective learning trajectories based on that perspective. The project begins with careful analysis of the E-D curriculum embodied in Russian mathematics materials, of classroom data from a Hawaii implementation of the E-D curriculum, and of relevant prior curriculum development projects in other U. S. contexts. Work is proceeding from development of an initial curriculum framework through intensive teaching experiments to implementation and modification of the framework in the course of classroom design experiments.

The ultimate product of the research and development effort will be a rational number learning progression consisting of carefully articulated and sequenced learning goals. The curriculum framework will also include mathematical tasks to foster learning of each concept, description of predicted student learning in the context of the tasks, a set of assessment items related to each concept, and guidelines for relevant teacher interventions. Thus, the framework will provide a foundation for development of curriculum units.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Measurement Approach to Rational Number (MARN) Project continued the empirical and theoretical work of the Learning Through Activity (LTA) research program. The LTA research program is motivated by the question: How do human learners develop mathematical concepts, and how can instruction engage and support these learning processes in service of developing particular mathematical concepts? Our premise is that to improve the scientific nature of mathematics instruction, mathematics education researchers need to better understand the process by which individuals construct new mathematical concepts.

In the MARN Project we conducted longitudinal single-subject teaching experiments through which the subjects built a series of fraction concepts. The MARN Project resulted in three types of contributions. The first was a set of theoretical contributions. We specified mathematical concept as a research construct -- previously an underspecified and imprecise term. We elaborated and symbolized reflective abstraction for the purpose of explicating mathematical concept learning. We extended Tzur and Simon’s stage distinction in mathematical concept learning. We created a typology for reversibility of mathematical concepts and identified two ways of promoting reversibility through instruction. Finally, we continued the development of an instructional design approach for promoting mathematical concepts.

The second type of contribution was the development of a specific adaptation of the single-subject teaching experiment to study conceptual learning. Using the instructional design approach, the MARN project demonstrated how researchers could study the transition from one concept to the next, not just the conceptual steps through which a learner passes.

The third type of contribution was the production of eleven empirically-based hypothetical learning trajectories (HLTs). Each HLT outlined a plan to foster fraction concepts through the students’ activity in response to a carefully sequenced set of mathematical tasks. The elven HLTs were:

  • · Initial Concept of Fraction: Fraction-as-Measure
  • · Improper Fraction
  • · Comparing Fractions
  • · Relation of Mixed Number and Improper Fraction
  • · Fraction of a Set: Fraction of a Whole Number with Whole Number Result
  • · Recursive Partitioning: Unit Fraction of a Unit Fraction
  • · Equivalent Fractions
  • · Addition of Fractions
  • · Subtraction of Fractions
  • · Meaning of Multiplication (Towards a unified concept for whole-number and fraction multiplication)
  • · Reinvention of Multiplication-of-Fractions Algorithm
